entry.title: HowTo install a virtualization plateform with KVM
entry.summary:
This tutorial describes how to install a virtualization plateform with KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) on Gentoo Linux. This plateform is based on Kernel modules, QEMU (Quick Emulator), VirtIO and VHostNet.

Then, LibVirt provides a convenient way to manage virtual machines on this plateform. LibVirt include an API library, a daemon (libvirtd), command line tools (virsh and virt-install) and a graphic tool (virt-manager). All these softwares are sponsorted by Red Hat.

Obviouly, this virtualization plateform uses Intel Virtualization Technologyy like VT-x (Virtualization Technology eXecution) and VT-d (Virtualization Technology for Directed I/O). KVM can also support VT-c (Intel® Virtualization Technology for Connectivity) but my laptop does not have this technology.

Kernel configuration

This is the configuration for Gentoo kernel 4.0.5.

Enable KVM

| [*] Virtualization  --->
|      | --- Virtualization
|      | <*>   Kernel-based Virtual Machine (KVM) support
|      | <*>     KVM for Intel processors support
|      | < >     KVM for AMD processors support (NEW)
|      | [ ]     Audit KVM MMU (NEW)
|      | [ ]     KVM legacy PCI device assignment support

Enable VirtIO driver

|     Device Drivers  --->
|      |
|      | [*] Network device support  --->
|      |        | <*>     Virtio network driver
|      |
|      |     Virtio drivers  --->
|      |        | <*> PCI driver for virtio devices
|      |        | [*]   Support for legacy virtio draft 0.9.X and older devices (NEW)
|      |        | <*> Virtio balloon driver
|      |        | <*> Platform bus driver for memory mapped virtio devices
|      |        | [*]   Memory mapped virtio devices parameter parsing

Enable VHostNet

| [*] Virtualization  --->
|      | --- Virtualization
|      | <*>   Host kernel accelerator for virtio net (NEW)

Enable virtual network (Local bridge with NAT)

| [*] Networking support  --->
|      | --- Networking support
|      |       Networking options  --->
|      |
|      |        | [*] Network packet filtering framework (Netfilter)  --->
|      |        |       | [*]   Advanced netfilter configuration
|      |        |       |       Core Netfilter Configuration  --->
|      |        |       |       | <*>   ctmark target and match support
|      |        |       |       | <*>   CHECKSUM target support
|      |        |       | <*>   Ethernet Bridge tables (ebtables) support  --->
|      |        |       |       | <*>   ebt: nat table support
|      |        |       |       | <*>   ebt: mark target support
|      |        |
|      |        | [*] QoS and/or fair queueing  --->
|      |        |       | <*>   Hierarchical Token Bucket (HTB)
|      |        |       | <*>   Stochastic Fairness Queueing (SFQ)
|      |        |       | <*>   Ingress Qdisc
|      |        |       | <*>   Netfilter mark (FW)
|      |        |       | <*>   Universal 32bit comparisons w/ hashing (U32)
|      |        |       | [*]   Actions
|      |        |       | <*>     Traffic Policing

Installation

Define compilation option

# nano /etc/portage/package.use

app-emulation/libvirt           qemu virt-network
app-emulation/libvirt-glib      python
app-emulation/qemu              qemu_softmmu_targets_x86_64 spice usbredir
app-emulation/virt-manager      gtk sasl
net-dns/dnsmasq                 script
net-firewall/iptables           conntrack ipv6
media-libs/mesa                 gles2

Start installation

# emerge libvirt virt-manager

Disable authentication for LibVirtd (Only for socket access)

# nano /etc/libvirt/libvirtd.conf

auth_unix_ro = "none"
auth_unix_rw = "none"

Change the default repository for disk images

# rmdir /var/lib/libvirt/images
# ln -s /mnt/data/VirtualMachine /var/lib/libvirt/images

Add user in KVM group

# gpasswd -a <username> kvm

Start libvirtd

# /etc/init.d/libvirtd start

Connection to LibVirtd

Start virt-manager

$ virt-manager

Open the menu "file > Add connection"

Create a virtual machine

Open the menu "file > New Virtual Machine"

Select "VirtIO" device model for Network Interface

entry.title: CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)
entry.summary:
CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is a mechanism, define by W3C, which provides a way for web servers to support cross-site access controls, which enable secure cross-site data transfers.

This mechanism works by adding new HTTP headers named Access-Control-Allow-Origin.

Step 1 : Create WebService

Create a PHP script named "cors.php" and hosted on "www.example.com" :

<?
  header("Access-Control-Allow-Origin: http://hostname:8000");
  echo date("Y-m-d H:i:s");
?>

Step 2 : Create HTML web page

Create a HTML file named "cors.html" and hosted on your computer :

<!doctype html>
<html>
 <body>

 <script>
  var xmlHttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xmlHttp.open( "GET", "http://www.example.com/cors.php", false );
  xmlHttp.send( null );
  alert(xmlHttp.responseText);
 </script>

 </body>
</html>

To test easily, start a web server with python (in the directory where the file "cors.html" is located)

python -m SimpleHTTPServer

Then, open web page from http://hostname:8000/cors.html

entry.title: JSONP (JSON with Padding)
entry.summary:
This article shows how JSONP (JavaScript Object Notation with Padding) can be used to get data from different domains, bypassing SOP (Same-Origin Policy).

JSONP uses the script tag, which is not in the scope of the SOP. Indeed, a JavaScript source file loaded from another domain will run in the origin of the HTML that includes the script, not in the domain where the JavaScript file originated from.

Step 1 : Create JSONP WebService

The web service encapsulates data, in JSON format, in a callback function. Create a PHP script named "jsonp.php" and hosted on "www.example.com" :

<?
 $MyData = '{ "MyDateTime": "' . date("Y-m-d H:i:s") . '" }';
 echo $_GET['JsonpCallback'] . '(' . $MyData . ');';
?>

Step 2 : Create HTML web page

The HTML page loads the JavaScript source file, from JSONP WebService, then execute the callback function. Create the HTML page named jsonp.html and hosted on your localhost :

<!doctype html>
<html>
 <head>

  <script type="text/javascript">

    function LoadJavaScript() {
      var script = document.createElement('script');
      script.src = 'http://www.example.com/jsonp.php?JsonpCallback=MyJsonpCallbackFunction';
      document.body.appendChild(script);
    }

    function MyJsonpCallbackFunction(DataArgument) {
      var MyJson = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(DataArgument));
      alert(MyJson["MyDateTime"]);
    }

  </script>

 </head>
 <body>
   <button type="button" onclick="LoadJavaScript();">Click me to display Date and Time</button>
 </body>
</html>

JSONP limits

JSONP only supports Cross-Origin HTTP GET request. Even more, the server could be compromised and return arbitrary code that will be executing in the context of your page (thus allowing access to your site’s cookies, localStorage, ...)

References

  • Code Project, JSON to JSONP: Bypass Same-Origin Policy
  • Phocean.net - Computer Security Blog, (in)Security of JSONP: CSRF risks

entry.title: SOP (Same-Origin Policy)
entry.summary:
SOP (Same Origin Policy) is a security mechanism implemented in browsers to restrict interactions between 2 different origin resources. Two resources have the same origin if the protocol, port, and host are the same for both resources.

This article shows how to test the SOP (Same Origin Policy) mechanism implemented by your browser.

Step 1 : Create WebService

Create a PHP script named "sop.php" and hosted on "www.example.com" :

<?
  echo date("Y-m-d H:i:s");
?>

Step 2 : Create HTML web page

Create a HTML file named "sop.html" and hosted on your localhost :

<!doctype html>
<html>
 <body>

 <script>
  var xmlHttp = new XMLHttpRequest();
  xmlHttp.open( "GET", "http://www.example.com/sop.php", false );
  xmlHttp.send( null );
  alert(xmlHttp.responseText);
 </script>

 </body>
</html>

Step 3 : Display error message

Open the file "sop.html" in a browser. The cross-origin request is blocked by the browser and the following message is displayed in the debbugging console :

Cross-Origin Request Blocked: The Same Origin Policy disallows reading the remote resource at http://www.example.com/sop.php. This can be fixed by moving the resource to the same domain or enabling CORS.

entry.title: TLS: Hardened configuration
entry.summary:
In recent years, many vulnerabilities (BEAST, CRIME, FREAK, ...) have been published about TLS protocol. Today, it is essential to enhanced configuration of TLS protocol to ensure the security of communication. This article lists the best practices to enhanced configuration of TLS protocol.

entry.title: TLS: Understanding the cipher suites
entry.summary:
To protect your communications, TLS protocol uses 4 cryptographic functions: key exchange, authentication, encryption and message authentication code. Cipher suite allows to define the algorithm used for each of these 4 functions.

Cryptographic function

Key exchange

This cryptographic function is used to define a common secret (the master secret key) between two parties. Available algorithms are RSA, DH, DHE and ECDHE.

Authentication

This cryptographic function is used to authenticate the server by client and optionally the client by server. Available algorithms are RSA or DSS.

Encryption

This cryptographic function is used to encrypt data. Available algorithms are DES, 3DES, RC4, AES, ...

Message Authentication Code

This cryptographic function is used to sign data. Available algorithms are MD5, SHA, SHA256, ...

Cipher suites

Cipher suite is a list of one or more cipher strings separated by special char (colon, comma, space, ...). The names for cipher suites are defined by IANA (Internet Assigned Numbers Authority).

Cipher suite defines algorithms used for each cryptographic function: key exchange, authentication, encryption and message authentication code. If algorithm for key exchange is not mentioned, default algorithm is RSA.

The table below details some example of cipher suites:

Value Cipher Suite Key Exchange Authentication Encryption MAC
0x00,0x04 TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5 RSA RSA RC4 128 MD5
0x00,0x05 TLS_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA RSA RSA RC4 128 SHA
0x00,0x0A TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA RSA RSA 3DES EDE CBC SHA
0x00,0x2F TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA RSA RSA AES 128 CBC SHA
0x00,0x35 TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA RSA RSA AES 256 CBC SHA
0x00,0x3C TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256 RSA RSA AES 128 CBC SHA 256
0x00,0x3D TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA256 RSA RSA AES 256 CBC SHA 256
0x00,0x9C TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 RSA RSA AES 128 GCM SHA 256
0x00,0x9D TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 RSA RSA AES 256 GCM SHA 384
0xC0,0x11 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA ECDHE RSA RC4 128 SHA
0xC0,0x12 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA ECDHE RSA 3DES EDE CBC SHA
0xC0,0x13 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA ECDHE RSA AES 128 CBC SHA
0xC0,0x14 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA ECDHE RSA AES 256 CBC SHA
0xC0,0x27 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256 ECDHE RSA AES 128 CBC SHA 256
0xC0,0x28 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA384 ECDHE RSA AES 256 CBC SHA 256
0xC0,0x2F TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 ECDHE RSA AES 128 GCM SHA 256
0xC0,0x30 TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 ECDHE RSA AES 256 GCM SHA 384
